description: You arrive in a quaint village nestled at the edge of the wilds. Cobblestone paths, wooden homes, and distant laughter fill the air. Something about this place feels safe... but not without mystery.
name: Village

story_actions.story_text: A hooded villager steps forward. You... don't look like you're from here.
The forest's been talking. Something stirs beyond the stone hill.
My brother went looking. Days ago. Hasn’t come back.
I saw his trail. It led into the hollow grove. Will you look for him?
You agree to help and note the direction of the hollow grove.
Talk to the old blacksmith sharpening a blade.
Pet a friendly village dog.
Read the weathered notice board near the inn.
Peek inside the chapel — old and still, candles flickering inside.
The villager listens in silence. So he’s gone then... Thank you. He deserved peace.
You return to the village. The air feels heavier, your steps slower. The grove has left its mark on you.

The elder watches you from afar. As you pass, he stops you. 'You saw it, didn’t you? The grove has stirred — it hasn’t spoken in years.'

He lowers his voice. 'There was another place, once. Older. Stone and silence. Some say it reshaped those who entered.'
Some say it teaches the path of rebirth. But few return from the temple unchanged.

You speak of the temple — how the ritual failed, how something was missing.

The Elder frowns. 'Long ago, there was something... left behind. Sealed away, perhaps. It’s only a shadow in my mind now.'

He gestures vaguely toward the outskirts of the village. 'Old places sometimes remember what people forget.'
You begin exploring the overgrown outskirts of the village. The land is quiet, half-swallowed by nature. Something feels near, but you’ll need more time.
After searching and subtle signs, the foliage parts. You find it: a sealed stone structure, covered in moss and memory. You sense its importance immediately.
You brace against the sealed vault door. You are ready. The stone creaks under the pressure — and shifts.
You fit the key into the rusted lock. A sharp click echoes from deep within the vault. It’s open.
The Elder calls to you quietly. 'You found it, didn’t you? The stone place. I dreamt of it again. There was a key. I gave it away — to someone I trusted. A quiet girl, always among the herbs.'
Help harvest turnips in the outer fields. Each root adds to the village’s store for the winter ahead.
Trade your bundle of turnips for lantern oil — a resource more precious now as the nights grow longer.
Deliver the lantern oil to the chapel keeper. With your help, the dusk lighting ceremony will continue.
The village elder notices your steady contributions. 'You’ve done much for this place. It remembers.'
Visit the smithy and watch sparks fly as iron meets anvil.
Help the herbalist sisters dry bundles of lavender and yarrow.
Bring herbs to the chapel to prepare for dusk rites.
Read the public noticeboard — faded ink, fresh concerns.

You meet Elder Branna near the well. She tells you of a massive landslide that has buried the forest path to the east. 'It fell after a quake some winters ago. We've sent for help, but none came. That path must be cleared. There are people waiting.'

The blacksmith crosses his arms. 'That landslide? It's not just rubble. There's old stone, roots grown thick, and slabs heavier than oxen. You'd need the strength of ten men and something to shift the earth itself.'
Attempt to clear the landslide blocking the eastern path.

You see a woman sorting herbs near the well. She nods as you approach but says little.

A nearby villager whispers, 'That's Lyra. Brings herbs to the chapel every dusk. She doesn't speak much, but she listens.'
The chapel priest frowns. 'Lyra’s late. She never misses dusk rites. If you’re heading that way, could you check on her? She gathers herbs near the southern trail.'

You find Lyra crouched beside the trail, carefully bundling herbs. She glances up, surprised. 'I... didn’t expect help.'

You gather beside her in silence, working until her basket is full.
You speak to Lyra of the vault — of the old stone and the silence within. Her expression shifts, almost imperceptibly. She nods once, then returns to her gathering.
Lyra presses something into your hand. A rusted key. Her eyes don’t meet yours. 'The old place… you’ll understand when you see it.'

You glimpse Lyra placing herbs gently on the chapel steps. She doesn't enter, but her gaze lingers on the altar.

A soft voice reaches your ear: 'Some burdens don’t need words.'
You return to the moss-covered ruins near the Vault. Old stone supports crumble beneath your tools — but from their remains, you carve dowels shaped by forgotten hands.
You ask the smith if he has any braces strong enough for bridge work. He snorts. 'You’re building something that matters, huh? Earn it. Fire’s hot. Hammer’s ready.'
You take your place at the forge. Each strike brings shape to molten iron. The smith says little, but nods once after every brace.
As you prepare to leave, the smith wipes his hands on a rag. 'You worked harder than most would've.' He pauses, then nods toward the cooling braces. 'That bridge — it’ll hold. Because you held.'

The smith sees you returning from the east. He doesn't ask — just watches you with a steady look.

'They say the bridge holds.' He sets down his tools. 'Didn’t think anyone would pull it off. But you… you remind me of how things used to be built — slow, solid, earned.'
